title: Antoine Dodson, viral video star, arrested for marijuana possession
text: Antoine Dodson, the star of the Bed Intruder video, was arrested Saturday for possession of marijuana and other misdemeanor charges. Dodson became an Internet sensation after video of a news story about the attempted rape of his sister, featuring his passionate, ultimately humorous threat to the perpetrator, was given the autotune treatment and went viral on YouTube. Dodson is speaking publicly about his arrest through Twitter. He tweeted about his arrest Saturday and created the hashtag # HappyCourtDateAntoine. Let me be the first to tell it!! So just got out of jail off a weak charge. LmaORoTfF!!!!! Got pulled over in my (cont) less than a minute ago via TweetCaster Favorite Retweet Reply Antoine Dodson antoinedodson24 Fellow viral video star Ted Williams has suffered a similar fall from Internet granted grace. Williams went from homeless to gainfully employed after video of his radio perfect voice went viral. But as the recovering drug and alcohol addicts past was revealed, the story quickly went from uplifting to something a little sadder in only two weeks. Williams was arrested, but not charged, in January after he and his daughter argued in a Los Angeles hotel. The next day he admitted he wasnt sober on the Dr. Phil show and entered rehab. Now his story is taking another familiar turn: hes currently filming a reality show . Do the viewers who make these average people Internet celebs hold some responsibility for their fates? Let us know in the comments.
gens_article:
April 25, 2011
Former resident of Washington City Council member Antoine Dodson has been arrested for possession of marijuana in the first degree. Dodson was picked up on a warrant last Friday when he had cut a deal with the city’s police department for voluntary reduction of charges. The arrest, released last week, also came after he resigned from council – owing him $2,676 in 2014 and $2,464 in 2015.
When 18-year-old Dodson was selected to join the early stages of the D.C. General Assembly, he stayed put, staying on for at least one month – until he was arrested and detained at DCC and charged with possession of marijuana.
As part of his deal with the city, Dodson was placed on a three-year probationary period, and he served jail time on similar charges. In the pre-trial intervention case, he was also charged with possession of the drug by a private individual, which included serving a jail time. According to his arrest report, Dodson claimed to have experienced a problem while in the city, claiming to “physically get dirtier and jerky.”
Dodson responded, speaking mostly in hushed tones and using a positive characterization of the officer as “a super nice guy.” He maintained that there was no police officer involved but said, “I was told all day they arrested me and I hadn’t even stepped out of the area to test my breath. My owner who’s my personal physician said I would give them the clean-up so we wouldn’t just turn in dirtier guys.”
According to Dodson’s arrest report, no one appears to have been driving an old white Chevy Blazer owned by one of his past congressional campaign campaign supporters.
Dodson will be held on $300 a day, which means he spent about four hours in jail on Thursday, where police originally believed he had alcohol or drug problems. He turned himself in to DCC police station with a $1,500 bond.
Did you know that before Dodson was arrested for the marijuana deal, he appeared in a video posted online that depicts him smoking a joint.
In a Facebook post, Steve Bush, Dodson’s campaign chief, writes:
“When footage was posted this morning using a former volunteer and uploaded to YouTube a user called PoliticalDog.
“He showed pictures of dozens of papers, including IPR, signed by a potential candidate.
“He says the papers were thrown in a dumpster by the top police department without making any of them appear in public.
“It is clear that the video is far from legit. [I asked Jim] Levitt, the beat cop, who’s trained with [offensive images] and is in charge of attracting media attention to his job, why is he allowing the video to go online?
“FORT LAUDERDALE police played them both. If you are a victim of this before, if you are under the age of 13, you should be automatically charged with a felony for not showing up to court.”
Co-founder of PoliticalDog.com, the Bush-campaign staffers-turned-victims website, Jordan Zimmerman and Jameel Thomas, reached out to Dodson yesterday to release a statement.

title: Marijuana legalization: Is the war on drugs working?
text: Are we winning the war on drugs? Nope. While thats not a direct quote, it seems to summarize the conclusions of a high-level commission that aims to rethink global drug policies. In a new report , the group recommends legalization of marijuana and calls for drug policies guided by health care and human rights -- not criminal justice. The groups conclusions are the latest challenge to Americas war on drugs. The way Global Commission on Drug Policy sees things, democracy is threatened by the corruption and violence connected with the drug trade and U.S. efforts arent helping things. The debate is particularly hot in Mexico, where drug cartels selling to the American users have led increasingly brazen attacks on fellow citizens in an attempt to maintain profits and fear. Some already wonder if Mexico is a failed state . Its an awkward time for the war on drugs. While federal officials have maintained their stance -- under both Republican and Democratic administrations -- state governments and voters have been approving new medical marijuana laws that are at odds with federal ones . Even the changing political tides seem to be working against the war on drugs. The rise of Rep. Ron Paul (R-Tx.) and other libertarians like fellow 2012 candidate Gary Johnson reflect a portion of American society that seeks less government intervention in the lives of citizens. Did you catch Ron Pauls take on heroin at the last GOP debate?
gens_article:
The controversial Issue: Marijuana is exploding with potent demand.
On April 10, People for the Ethical Treatment of Marijuana reported that the U.S. National Survey on Drug Use and Health (NDRH) found 88 percent of Americans now use marijuana to treat and treat an ancillary disease: agitation. That’s 18 times more people in the United States now using marijuana than alcohol.
And not just alcohol: By 2009, 6 percent of Americans were considering marijuana use or recreational use. Those figures jumped to 13 percent in 2010. In 2015, as more Americans age (versus teens and adults), marijuana use was more than 25 times the rate among adults.
What if all that being said, does it really matter if Americans believe that law enforcement has acted as it does to crack down on medical marijuana use?
No. Mostly because there isn’t any war on drugs. That’s because marijuana is legal in the United States. And that is what has led people to think: That legalizing pot is the wrong thing to do.
Now, people expect it will get popular, but if they don’t, the federal government could start taking action, whether we want to call it terrorism or criminal activity.
McClatchy reports the National League of Cities (NLC) is investigating whether the federal government should regulate marijuana. Like the Washington Metropolitan Area Council, NLC is based in the West: "The NLC’s aggressive goal is to ensure that pot prohibition continues as long as states have proven it to be legal and safe."
For its part, however, the DEA distorts the legality of marijuana by saying it is “culturally distinct and is different from marijuana … Weed is legal for medical, recreational and recreational use.”
Some skeptical observers – though they could be wrong – think that those words mean the Justice Department and FBI should actually investigate the possibility of marijuana being banned in the United States.
The DEA: “Federal law enforcement recognizes that making a statement to police about a joint activity in the United States, particularly after a joint trip, is very different from a statement that is made to the public.”
I’m far from a fan of the federal government’s answer to cancer. They may say this is completely legal, but be otherwise naïve. Would they really tell me that legalizing marijuana would put them in jail? Probably not.
Marijuana and medicine can both fall under the Federal Marijuana Act of 1986. The act says marijuana should be banned from the possession and use of any adult only in one state. Proponents note the law gets rid of the constitutional amendment to ban it, but still say the purity of pot has been right up until now.
Groups who support the legalization of marijuana say decriminalizing marijuana should be provided with pot-based tax programs, grants and special exemptions. But if the federal government forces people with addiction problems to violate federal law and spend taxpayer money on treatment, the consequences could be dire.
Such efforts have been met with massive political and constitutional resistance.

title: Willie Nelson’s marijuana-related plea deal rejected
text: Willie Nelsons latest marijuana-related legal woes arent over yet. A judge has rejected a plea deal that would have Nelson plead guilty to possession of drug paraphernalia and pay a $500 fine. The country music legend was arrested in November after six ounces of marijuana were found on his tour bus. The deal was rejected Wednesday by Judge Becky Dean-Walker, who told the AP that Nelson should be charged with misdemeanor marijuana possession. The red-headed stranger could face a year in jail if convicted. This seems like a harsh turn in a case where an attorney said Nelson could get off with a fine if he sang Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain . Sadly, Dean-Walker later said the offer was a joke that got out of hand. This is not the first time Nelson, who has appeared on multiple High Times covers and in the 1998 film Half Baked, has been arrested for marijuana-related crimes. He was sentenced to six months probation for a misdemeanor count of marijuana possession in 2007.
gens_article:
He may have a deal that will save Willie Nelson’s life.
In a deal hammered out between the case’s prosecutors and defense attorneys last week, a plea deal was struck with Willie Nelson, who is still a free man after being granted a drug-related arrest. The sale of marijuana in Colorado, where Willie Nelson was found dead in his ranch outside of Littleton, Colo., became known as the “herd child” because it was banned from interstate commerce for a year. Prosecutors said Willie Nelson paid at least $150,000 for the drug, yet Willie Nelson was back in hiding.
But Willie Nelson made a move, and applied for a plea deal, according to The Washington Post’s Dana Loesch. “Although he resisted further contact with the authorities, Willie Nelson recommended that prosecutors look at the possibility of getting him to cooperate with the investigation,” Loesch writes. “Specifically, a deal would have allowed Willie Nelson’s cooperation to be overseen by the Department of Justice’s Special Agent in Charge in Colorado, Gregg Hicks.”
Also on Monday, Willie Nelson’s defense attorney Brian Drummond said in a statement that the government, known as “DAPA,” has stopped making “a profit from Mr. Nelson’s brief appearance” in Colorado, meaning Willie Nelson will not be called as a witness in his felony case. Drummond said that even if Willie Nelson is found guilty, his plea deal “doesn’t solve the crime, but it will allow a low-level individual from Connecticut to gather money off Willie Nelson for years, at a price that is more than ordinary.”

title: D.C. police cracking down on ‘fake pot’
text: The operators of three shops in Adams Morgan and two gas station convenience stores in Anacostia have received written notice that they risk having business assets seized and forfeited under federal law if they sell fake pot, commonly marketed as K2 or Spice. Narcotics investigators for the Metropolitan Police on Monday began visiting stores where they said they had previously made undercover buys or learned of sales of synthetic marijuana, said Inspector Brian Bray, commander of narcotics and special investigations. Another three convenience stores are set to receive visits, Bray said. The product is not illegal under District law or under state law in Maryland, although there have been proposals to outlaw it in both places. Virginia recently banned synthetic marijuana. Spice cannot be detected by current urine testing methods and has become popular among military members, parolees and probationers who face random drug checks, said Bray. Eleven midshipmen have been expelled since January from the U.S. Naval Academy for using or possessing Spice in what is described as an ongoing investigation. On March 1, the Drug Enforcement Administration banned five chemicals that are used to treat herbs to make them mimic the effects of marijuana. The DEA is empowered to put a substance temporarily in Schedule I to avoid an imminent threat to public safety and acted, its spokesmen said, after increasing reports from emergency room doctors of convulsions, elevated heart rates and anxiety attacks among other side effects. At the time of the DEA ban, 16 states had outlawed the herbal mix, which often is packaged in foil envelopes and labeled as incense. Bray said it is selling in the District for about $40 a gram. Users in the District could be prosecuted due to the DEAs action, but it likely would be a minor drug case for federal court, said Bray, which is why investigators are focusing on putting stores on formal notice they stand to forfeit business assets for selling and distributing products containing the banned chemicals. In addition to Spice and K2, the fake pot is sold as Wicked X, Bliss, Black Mamba, Bombay Blue, Fake Weed, Genie, Blaze, Dream, Ex-Ses, Spark, Fusion, Dark Knight, Yucatan Fire, Sonic, AK-47, Atomic Orange and Zohai.
gens_article:
The Bothell police have arrested five suspects at the estate of former Washington Attorney General Bob Ferguson, who became disillusioned after he went to jail on bank fraud charges in 1998.
Peter Flint, a fifth suspect arrested in the case, was charged Friday with possession of marijuana.
Police say Flint was able to conceal his use of the drug using an ordinary envelope stuffed with $400 in cash. The change of possession can’t be seen by police from that envelope’s photo.
“It was at an O.C. address, and he changed it to his own house,” said DC Police spokesman Officer Jason Judd, a spokesman for the precinct that investigates suspicious activity. “The man noted some political and religious ties and he explained that he didn’t have the goods to be convicted of receiving it.”
According to Judd, Flint was a criminal who moved around from town to town when he moved to Bothell, where he filled in on policy meetings.
Before he took charge of DC’s Office of Law Enforcement and Oversight, Flint served as attorney general for the District of Columbia for nine years under the Nixon administration, which included close ties to the Democratic Party and a long grudge-swapping with then-White House Chief of Staff Ben Cardin.
On one occasion during his brief time in office, the federal prosecutor assigned to prosecute him alleged that Flint had targeted black homeowners who got into trouble by running afoul of their property-law convictions.
D.C. law-enforcement investigators began tracking Flint after he filed a petition against himself with the Department of Justice in October 2000.
Jackson Burch, 18, and Melvin Moore, 23, were arrested in March 2004, charged with wire fraud, bank fraud, and mail fraud. They each received a warning letter for turning over a mortgage and other payment information.
“They were all just trying to keep it quiet,” Jackson Burch said. “It was about the case. I know that they were really unhappy with where I was located, and I know the people who stayed in the East Village and saw where I was located.”
Mary Pat Flaherty contributed to this report.

title: Report: Elijah Dukes tried to eat bag of marijuana after traffic stop
text: A routine traffic stop turned into yet another bizarre chapter in the troubled life of former Major League Baseball player Elijah Dukes. After Tampa police pulled over the 27-year-olds orange Chevy Camero early Thursday, Dukes tried to eat a small bag of marijuana , as first reported by the Tampa Tribune. Dukes was charged with drug possession, tampering with physical evidence, possession of drug paraphernalia and three counts of driving with a canceled or suspended license. He was not, however, cited for watching Super Troopers one too many times. According to records obtained by the Tribune, Dukes has been arrested dozens of times since 2001, including charges related to domestic violence and failure to pay child support. The Tampa Bay Rays selected Dukes in the third-round of the 2002 draft. He was released by Washington in 2010 after spending two up-and-down seasons with the Nationals. Last February, Dukes began rapping under the name Fly Eli, and in a Tampa Tribune story, said he would sometimes smoke marijuana before Nationals home games. Dukes also said he felt he had been blackballed by baseball after he came forward alleging fellow players were smuggling drugs onto chartered planes and using them in their hotel rooms. Major League Baseball refuted Dukes claims . Dukes, who has six children with four different women, was suspended in each of his first five professional seasons.
gens_article:
Wearing a wig, wary of the sight of a car on the street, Elijah Dukes was out and about Thursday night when he noticed a car on the median weaving in and out of traffic, according to a police report. Dukes went into a red SUV to check if anyone was in the vehicle and found the driver, 55-year-old Elijah Bradford, smelled of marijuana, he said.
Then, something happened, said Dukes, who ran into the car, waved off the driver, and drove away. Then two shots were fired. The driver, who has not been identified, shot at the trooper that Dukes said was driving, when he fled on foot, Dukes said.
The trooper made a quick pursuit, which went to two blocks north of the intersection with Talen Drive. By that point, a car stopped but all six occupants got out, police said.
The chase ended, but didn’t move at all. With the New York Giants still on the run, Dukes was thrown into the back of the police car. The senior at the New Oxford school in Lutherville, Maryland, was taken by armored car to Ashburn military hospital.
[Warning: Drinker’s Notes]

title: Vincent Orange proposes capping D.C. marijuana sites
text: Well, Vincent Orange said hed fill the leadership void in Ward 5 during the months it will go without a D.C. Council member . His void-filling has wasted no time. Orange informed his colleagues today that hes proposing an emergency bill that will place limits on the number of medical marijuana facilities that can go in any particular ward. He would like a vote as soon as next Tuesday. Under the draft bill circulated Thursday by Orange, only five marijuana cultivation centers could be permitted in any single ward. As for dispensaries, where medical pot would actually be retailed, Orange aims to limit those to only two per ward. Also, if a ward has five or more cultivation centers, no dispensary could locate there. This is of particular interest to Ward 5, where most marijuana entrepreneurs are looking to open up their facilities as documented by DCist and the Washington Times. Orange represented the ward from 1999 to 2007. Former council member Harry Thomas Jr. had pondered a similar bill late last year, but, as it turned out, he had other matters to attend to . Many Ward 5ers including several who spoke at an Orange-hosted meeting Monday arent too jazzed about the prospect of legalized drug facilities, as theyre already quite annoyed about the concentration of strip clubs and other unsavory businesses in the ward. But theres a reason for that: Zoning restrictions keep many of those businesses from locating elsewhere in the city. Ward 5, with its relative surfeit of industrially zoned land and relative deficit of schools and other facilities that complicate the location of said unsavory businesses, just happens to be the main place these folks can legally go. There is nothing in the Orange bill that would address that problem, meaning the bill could be a de facto cap on the number of medical marijuana facilities above and beyond the caps contemplated in Health Department regulations (10 cultivation centers and five dispensaries). Update, 5:45 p.m..: Orange said hes not stopping with marijuana facilities; hes also aiming to cap the number of strip clubs, topless bars, gentlemens clubs, or adult entertainment establishments in a separate piece of legislation. I promised the Ward 5 leadership I was going to get this done, he said. A West Virginia Avenue NW establishment, Club AKA 55, has declared its intention to feature nude dancing, and Orange says he wants to nip the issue in the bud, as it were. If youre going to have a discussion on the cultivation centers and dispensaries, you might as well have a discussion on strip clubs as well, he said. Regarding the marijuana facilities, Orange said hes hoping his colleagues would see this oversaturation is unfair. For emergency legislation to pass, Orange needs nine votes out of 12. Asked whether he intends to address the zoning restrictions that are most responsible for said oversaturation, Orange said, that may be the product that comes out of this legislation. If its still determined 10 cultivation centers are needed, he said, maybe someone will present legislation to relax zoning regulations. What about Orange himself? Not at this point, he said.
gens_article:
An Arlington man proposes drastic changes to Washington’s marijuana industry in an effort to boost the Legislature’s lack of progressive policy toward marijuana—and thus influence in the future.
Veteran Washington marijuana entrepreneur Vincent Orange, who was born in Washington, D.C., and writes extensively about the industry in his new book, Dreams From the Weed, was promoting a a proposal this week to outlaw marijuana dispensaries.
Contrary to Florida and South Carolina’s laws, he’s seeking to amend the Controlled Substances Act to prohibit regulatory restrictions that will create a market. Many dispensaries currently operate under D.C. rules, but Orange says the regulations should be pulled from all state regulations as conditions.
“We are trying to create a market where marijuana cannot be sold in D.C.,” he says. “There are no dispensaries in Washington. It’s impossible for me to see anybody selling marijuana in D.C.”
From the Washington Post
The proposed legislation would:
— Create a division of general excise taxes to govern the sale of marijuana;
— Oppose government-sanctioned dealers;
— Crack down on “scientific” dispensaries like Andre’s Drug, which Orange shut down last year;
— Create a clear regulation of such stores and clarify that dispensaries that aren’t owned by individuals but licensed by the government won’t be allowed to sell marijuana.
Each proposal proposes banning existing medical marijuana shops that’s operated by individuals in Washington state. The group led by the lobbyist Wes Rojek, is also pushing for the creation of a state-approved adult pot dispensary that would be strictly regulated.
Since 2011, there have been a total of 8,853 people and 15,300 marijuana products sold in Washington. Critics have called the government takeover a flop, with activists calling it a “moral failure” and Democrats calling it a potential gift to criminalization. Critics have even gone so far as to challenge the findings of a study that Texas ranked among the nation’s largest providers of medical marijuana.
Now, Orange says “none of us think patients should have to make their own choice” about the path to treatment in such shops. And with dozens of people he says has completed medical marijuana treatment, “I think the best way to look at the expansion is to establish an end to this stupor and preserve as many aspects of the system as possible.”
On Tuesday, Orange also proposed a bill to expand access to an internet-based framework allowing individuals to file a complaint that marijuana is not growing in the community; he’s also calling for a ban on dispensaries in rural areas of D.C. He also said he favors giving judges greater discretion in determining whether dispensaries aren’t complying with state rules.
What prompted Orange to propose a ban on dispensaries in Washington?
“Someone told me it would ruin my business. You go to a dispensary and you say you come from Washington? And they say you come from Texas. I don’t know what hell is going on.”
In 2011, he told the Washington Post, “All of a sudden, as a new client starts meeting with me,” he was asked to post details of their business plans in his email. When reached for comment this week, Orange said the complaint will be dropped. He’s also eager to see how Vail’s drug treatment center works when it’s up and running.
A News and Observer poll found overwhelming support for legalizing medical marijuana in the District of Columbia, with 73 percent of those surveyed supporting the concept. A majority agreed that the District was the center of its industry, as well as the location of its dispensaries.
What do you think? Should we continue down the federal drug trade as the Mother Jones article does? Sound off in the comments section.

title: Why the marijuana issue is only going to get bigger
text: Marijuana legalization may be a bit of a quiet issue in this election year. But before long its going to get much bigger, moving into the electoral arena around the country and forcing itself into national debates in a way it hasnt been before, much as same-sex marriage did over the last few years. Were rapidly approaching the day when no politician with any significant ambitions can avoid having a well-considered position on the issue. Would-be public officials are going to be asked about it with increasing frequency, and it wont be enough to make a Cheech and Chong joketo change the subject. That isnt stopping them from trying, however. When Chris Christie got asked about legalization on his radio show, he said : For the people who are enamored with the idea with the income, the tax revenue from this, go to Colorado and see if you want to live theresee if you want to live in a major city in Colorado where theres head shops popping up on every corner and people flying into your airport just to come and get high. To me, its just not the quality of life we want to have here in the state of New Jersey and theres no tax revenue thats worth that. Officials from the rancid cauldron of sin and misery that is Colorado were quick to respond . From the beauty of the rolling hills of the Eastern Plains to the magnificent landscapes in the mountains and from our smallest rural towns to our largest cities, Colorado offers the greatest quality of life in the nation, said Senator Michael Bennett. A lot of people think Colorado is great place to live, work and play. Plus, we have a pretty awesome quality of life, said a spokesperson for Governor John Hickenlooper. Obviously, those guys must be high. This is something of a preview of the arguments well see as we move toward 2016 and legalization initiatives are on ballots all over the country. Youll notice that Christies argument was pragmatic, not moralistic. He didnt say that people who smoke pot are losers and criminals, or that its an instrument of evil. Instead he talked about the trade-offs between tax revenue and the vitality of urban shopping districts. Opponents of legalization realize that moralistic arguments against marijuana are going to be political losers, what with the fact that a majority of Americans now support legalization , plus the fact that most Americans have used it at some point in their lives . But that doesnt mean Republicans are going to come around to legalization any time soon,a factDemocrats hope will allow them to use ballot initiatives to burst turnout among some of their target constituencies. To be sure, this fall there may end up being only a couple of marijuana initiatives on the ballot. Florida voters will decide on a constitutional amendment providing for medical marijuana, and a full legalization initiative could make it to the ballot in Alaska . Advocates are also trying to put a measure on the ballot in Oregon . But if youre a legalization advocate,you actually shouldnt want to have an initiative on the ballot this year. In state after state, advocates have decided to wait until 2016, when they know more of Democrats and young people will be going to the polls to vote for president, to put the question to the voters. Advocates in California considered mounting a push this year, then put it off until 2016 . That presidential year could also see initiatives in Arizona, Maine, Massachusetts, Montana, and Nevada, and possibly other states as well. Theres a good reason for this: Polls show huge divides by age and party on theissue. Recent surveys by the Pew Research Center show that while only 32 percent of Americans over 65 favor legalization, 70 percent of those 18 to 29 favor it. The divide between parties is only slightly smaller, with 63 percent of Democrats favoring legalization compared to 39 percent of Republicans. With half a dozen or more states deciding legalization at the polls in 2016, it will be impossible for any politician to ignore. And after years of fruitful hippie-bashing, Republicans will find themselves increasingly on the defensive. And this issue is only going to get bigger and bigger.
gens_article:
Marijuana legalization is hitting the ground running in Washington. In passing legislation in the Senate in October, President Obama talked about legalizing marijuana for recreational use, pushing the ban on all but certain exemptions to the medical marijuana law, and widening recreational efforts to create jobs around the country.
Now marijuana is officially being talked about — in the same way food is now being talked about — in Washington as the state of Washington. As WTOP’s Rick Shpigel notes, to fight back against growing marijuana use in Washington, the Obama administration must persuade marijuana opponents that this may not be the goal.
So why did marijuana’s critics bring up the issue this week? A scientific study by researchers at Columbia University’s Mailman School of Public Health concludes that alcohol is almost certainly the most harmful contributor to a person’s early development, and they’ve watched the medical marijuana market expand from a small fraction of the dispensary market into a total of 13 percent of the marketplace.
However, there are a couple of reasons why prohibition has been palatable politically in Washington — small, homegrown entrepreneurs don’t have the same access to the public health authority that the medical marijuana legalization law permits. One reason is the simple fact that medical marijuana is relatively safe, and proponents of legalization are fearful that marijuana’s already threatening the livelihoods of developing countries that are reliant on food imports.
Another reason is Washington’s reliance on rice, which has a favorable genetic profile, can make it difficult for farmers to obtain the proper plant plants. “While marijuana does have the potential for increased food exports, it will take a while to appreciate the benefits of its potential as an agricultural item,” Shpigel writes. “However, if Washington really embraces the medicinal use of marijuana, it is likely to raise the cost of food for farmers.”
Finally, though Washington’s enforcement of medical marijuana law could go further than simply distributing medical marijuana to minors, the senators' struggle to keep the ban on enforcement appears to be a holding issue for both Democrats and Republicans.
Image: The State of Washington via Flickr.

title: The Insiders: Republicans, just say no to marijuana
text: There is no possible public good that can be derived from passing laws that legalize marijuana use, and Republicans should say so. With recently passed legalization laws going into effect in Colorado , and reports that New York is planning on loosening its marijuana laws, the best we can hope for is that these laws are written in a way that will protect the innocent as much as possible. Soon well be seeing the first reports of crime resulting from the marijuana business the DUIs, problems with underage access, etc. These are already problems associated with alcohol. Without question, we will face more human tragedy and ruined lives as a result of marijuana legalization. Tyler Williams of Blanchester, Ohio, selects marijuana strains to purchase at the 3-D Denver Discrete Dispensary on Jan. 1. Its not good policy to facilitate the opportunity for more inebriated people to wander among us. Legalizing marijuana is just not a good idea. Even my friend Ruth Marcus at XXX, who is not exactly a conservative commentator, said that widespread legalization is a bad idea, particularly because of the known negative impact smoking marijuana can have on adolescents and their development. She cited a 2012 study that found that persistent cannabis use was associated with neuropsychological decline broadly across domains of functioning. Republicans need to be clear on where they stand on this issue.We shouldnt think up reasons to do the wrong thing to try to look hip or appeal to reckless youth. If the Democrats think they have found an issue for 2014, let them be the ones to promise more pot to the population. And spare me the talk about personal freedom being at stake here. You arent more free if you are a pothead and freedom isnt measured by marijuana consumption.
gens_article:
Is this inevitable, or is the Republican Party past its prime?
Weeks before the midterm elections, the party that had wised up to the fact that marijuana taxes weren’t a popular issue, cast questions on marijuana legalization policy in a memo sent to top officials. In it, chief tea party strategist Richard Ben-Nelson outlines his concerns, and offers some suggestions.
One GOP memo suggested legalizing marijuana would have less of an impact on voter identification efforts, reducing turnout by 4 percentage points, but would not have affected general elections. The memo from Ben-Nelson, provided by Senator Tom Coburn, Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, makes no agreement with the GOP. He’s holding a conference of conservative Republicans in Wyoming last week to discuss the issue.
We suggest, if you like Republican Party, you don’t want to be alone on this.
When you accept the wisdom of the day, welcome home. Your moms, your dads, and/or your children. Put something on the ballot.
What do you want, a message, a welcome home message? This should represent your beliefs. Who has won this election?
Ugh, why? The American people believed in a “living constitution” and not Trump. We are told everything is fine (and also overrun, if you disagree) and now we are threatened by the specter of all these governments falling into ruin (or worse, failing). The matter of whether we are required to have reliable records like state and local record keeping can be a great blessing if we are punished harshly for voting against them or that we do not have the decency to pledge allegiance to the freedom that is our Founding Fathers. I do not propose any reformation or replacement (or repeal) of our founding documents (self-government, colonies, etc.).
The state of Pennsylvania was whipped for the committee meeting and I don’t believe it was based on a bad idea. I personally have led both parties that I know respect the sovereignty of a state and they have all shown loyalty, respect, and respect to each other. Pa. is the most popular state for all patriots; I have served in national politics. I have learned to love Pennsylvania. Read their patriotic motto and let’s pray that it will inspire other people to follow their advice.
Hire a recruiter. A few pejorative questions here…
Why would I hire a recruiter? The difference between a startup and an enterprise is they operate in an alternate universe, the same, you know. It’s the difference between a job interview and a job placement interview. The open-arena job interview is the easiest and quickest way to get up on top of the company. Let them know that they can do that job interview and they will. Furthermore, they will know that they are not hired for every role because they will have to have a degree or whatever. They could do that job interview themselves, and perhaps their offer could be an employee that they were interested in. If it wasn’t, they would be fired, and I don’t expect them to. If it wasn’t, they would not be hired anyway.
We can’t call you a sucker. But you’re a designer, a tennis consultant, an editor, and a dominatrix. Right?
In no way does your vote count. Insiders have done their jobs, but if you vote for political insurance against the veto, you can get sent out only a military and overseas brigade of members. Turnouts usually go less than 20%. Whatever happened to cheers?
We hope you find this amusing, and don’t hesitate to vote for a progressive nominee.

title: Legalizing pot could save California hundreds of millions every year, state says
text: A proposed ballot measure that would legalize possession, use, growth and cultivation of marijuana would save the state of California hundreds of millions of dollars a year, according to a summary issued Thursday by the state attorney generals office. The summary, which Attorney General Kamala Harriss (D) office releases for each proposed ballot measure, says the state would save in the low hundreds of millions of dollars annually on law enforcement costs associated with enforcing marijuana laws. As an added bonus, Harriss office said sales tax revenues could add more cash again, in the low hundreds of millions of dollars annually to the states bottom line. Supporters of the proposed ballot measure would need to collect 504,760 signatures by May 23 to get the initiative formally known by its ballot title, Marijuana Legalization. Initiative Statute on the 2014 ballot. The group backing legalization wont actually be collecting signatures for this version of the bill; the lead sponsor told the San Francisco Chronicle that they had tweaked the initiatives language to allow individuals to grow more marijuana for personal use. A revised version [pdf] of the ballot initiative, dubbed the Marijuana Control, Legalization and Revenue Act of 2014, is scheduled to be reviewed by the attorney generals office by the end of January, the Chronicle reported. Both versions of the measure would legalize the use, growth, cultivation, possession, transportation, storage and sale of marijuana, while creating a commission to regulate and issue business licenses for cultivation and sales. The measure would apply retail sales taxes to marijuana sold for recreational purposes, while allocating that money equally to education, health care, law enforcement and drug abuse programs. It also prevents state and local law enforcement officials from enforcing federal marijuana laws. Some California officials who back marijuana legalization had urged fellow supporters to wait until 2016, when the electorate will be larger, younger and more ethnically diverse, to put a measure on the fall ballot. But the ballot summary is so favorable that strategists think they will be able to pass the measure even in the lower-turnout midterm year. California has been in the vanguard of the pro-marijuana movement. The state was the first in the country to legalize the possession and use of marijuana for medical purposes, back in 1996. In 2010, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger (R) signed legislation decriminalizing possession of an ounce or less. If the ballot measure passes, California would be the third state to legalize marijuana, along with Washington and Colorado, where voters legalized the drug through ballot measures this year.
gens_article:
With an estimated 2 million people in California making marijuana use, the state could save billions of dollars per year if federal law applied, the state's chief legal officer has said.
Ted Smith told reporters on Monday night that the state will have a zero-tolerance approach toward marijuana use as a result of the legalization of recreational pot, which took effect late last month. Recreational marijuana is legal for adults 18 and older in California.
"We have enough land, but not enough stores and sufficient infrastructure to make it a $1 billion an investment in a bunch of warehouses, all of those warehouses," Smith said at a symposium hosted by the California Conference of the American Medical Association in San Francisco.
California's approach will be reviewed by lawmakers on Wednesday, and likely drafted as part of a $10 billion legislation that would limit the number of locations allowed to sell medical marijuana, create a 501(c)(3) entity to run polling places and tax services and open dispensaries to the public.
California voters approved medical marijuana with 91 percent of the vote, legalizing recreational use in June, and used up his budget savings by nine days to encourage doctors and others who treat chronic pain and other chronic ailments to prescribe it.
California currently has a fiscal crisis, where revenue from the state's legal pot pot revenue came in late in the fiscal year and the state had less than two months to make up for deficits caused by delayed state-funded pensions, transportation, and housing.
According to Thompson, California's chief medical officer, the issue is too complex for policymakers to solve, the state's rapidly growing population and the medical marijuana industry are both bottom-feeding and traditional business class, and need to be the first in the U.S. to get the benefits.
After dropping an order from a congressional committee in October, Smith joined the Senate Armed Services Committee in April to get the medical marijuana bill passed, delivering the first major passage of a bill which would have allowed doctors to write prescriptions for recreational marijuana.
Government agencies have given the state six months to remove the provisions they want from the statute, according to Sen. Dianne Feinstein, the chairwoman of the Senate committee.
Smith, who is under final review as chief medical officer, said medical marijuana has been allowed to work as long as six months, though he acknowledges that the marijuana industry is undergoing some nagging changes in its own control. While he did not specify how that changes could happen, he said that he expected it to take more time than originally planned.
He said residents have been asking him about ways to keep their medical marijuana laws more controlled, and that he will then need Congress to pass a standalone bill that is similar to the California version.
"Let me tell you, there are only three options for someone making these decisions," Smith said. "Let's deal with those three options: allow patients, allow states to regulate, let's build additional infrastructure that makes it possible for a future legalization of drugs in the state. You can pass other things without derailing and making this move ahead of other things that are on the ballot in California in 2016."

title: Looks like Democrats have a weed fight coming
text: The news today from Gallup is that, for the first time in its polling, a majority indeed, a solid majority of Americans back legalizing marijuana . So far, most politicians have stuck with support for the status quo, or perhaps the status quo plus various exemptions and loopholes. With 58 percent of all respondents and 65 percent of Democrats favoring legalization, however, theres now a very good chance that a fair number of ambitious Democratic politicians are going to sign up for full legalization as a way to differentiate themselves in Democratic primaries. Matt Yglesias suggests that Hillary Clinton will be among them . I think thats perhaps premature, but maybe not. The way this probably will unfold is that a fair number of candidates will take a legalization position, and some may even try to run hard on it, in 2014 elections and especially Democratic primaries. If its perceived to be successful, then expect Clintons competitors for 2016 to flirt with or perhaps even embrace the position. Only after that or at least, only after its clear that it will happen would I expect Clinton to go along. As a strong front-runner (and assuming shes running), expect Clinton to avoid positions that she perceives as dangerous in a general election, but also expect her to match Democrats who embrace issues that could divide the party. All of that analysis, for Clinton and the rest, is based on an assumption that candidates will react here to electoral incentives rather than their personal views of the issue. I think thats extremely likely in this case; Id be very surprised if more than a handful of candidates for Congress next year have strong personal feelings on this. In that, its probably very different from marriage; while obviously electoral incentives were important, I suspect a lot of politicians cared quite a bit about it on substantive grounds. Its true that there are some libertarian candidates who may try to run on the issue in Republican primaries, but, for the most part, its still going to be a loser there. And remember: just because most Democratic voters support legalization in polls doesnt mean that its a voting issue for them. But, yes, I do think theres a good chance that its going to be an issue Democratic politicians jump on in 2014 and 2016.
gens_article:
To the Democrats holding the House, it seems like a proposition we already already have: (See) The Democrats take control of the House after the shutdown ends and debate over raising the government.
We’re talking about House Speaker John Boehner, who, in advance of Friday’s big vote to reauthorize the 2012 health care law, called the shutdown “the worst week of his leadership” and warned that the shutdown would “never end” because he didn’t want to leave the opposition parties in the lurch. On the ground, since we can’t get the word out in a coordinated, ground-breaking way, Boehner said he’d accept the Speaker’s approach.
But the Democrats were in a state of “biologically incoherent confusion,” with no plausible way for Democrats to deal with the shutdown. It was this particular set of “credentials” that led many to think Republicans, at least initially, would know what it took to make a deal, and believe they could act on that to try to pass it. As one Republican legislator told me in an interview, this isn’t entirely true. From what I’ve seen, the reason that we haven’t seen that clear answer is that Congress was once again utterly unprepared to put aside partisan differences in addressing a very serious crisis.
You don’t find many Republicans willing to take on the longer-term issues, such as Medicare and Obamacare. No party that I know is willing to yield on those issues is quite willing to give up on something as grand as protecting Obamacare. But, in fact, there is a high degree of certainty that Republicans can somehow do a deal and win the election. The decision to keep the government shut down is one of the economic things Republicans don’t want to do, but it makes America a bit less popular.
Democrats may be winning this battle because of new information about the Democratic Caucus. I know two of them. I spoke to Chuck Rosenberg, the Democrat District of Columbia branch chair of the Senate Democratic Caucus, on Tuesday, and he told me how he, too, was able to agree to the leadership caucus plan without showing up for the vote. And Democratic members shepherded a series of suicide attempts last week. He has been waiting for the next straw.
Related: Clashes are keeping Republicans from getting the plan they need to pass. The danger in even sending “emergency” funds to the GOP still seems too great
There are several Democrats who are likely to defect and that may not bode well for the GOP chances this fall. Just to give you an idea of how many defections (including likely supporters of the minority party, many of whom are losing their jobs, and even some of them who have backed other minority-party commitments), I’ve got nine Democrats who have shifted away from the leadership caucus caucus. Right now, the rest of the DC delegation has about four to six defections.
What’s more, the Democratic caucus has got a stronger cause: The Democratic Party’s just failed congressional election, which many expect to break soon, and the point of the leadership caucus plan is that they will now be able to push forward on passing legislation to open or potentially reopen the government. And nobody worries that House Republicans will eventually act unilaterally, in order to force a vote on the administration’s controversial fiscal 2014 budget or some legislative maneuver that will supposedly close the budget.
That concession could be further sweetened if Democrats face a Christmas Day scramble to resolve some disputes among themselves over issues such as spending. A key question remains over whether the American people are ready for such a deal, and how much help would be available if they would not do the deal they claim they’re rejecting.
Jonathan Bernstein is a Distinguished Fellow of the Brookings Institution and a Senior Fellow of the Financial Times.
This article appears in the Washington Post’s September 25, 2013 issue of National Review Online.
Jonathan Bernstein is a Washington Post contributing writer.

title: D.C. arrests for public use of marijuana nearly tripled last year
text: Arrests for the public use of marijuana in the District nearly tripled in 2016 and are on track to remain high in 2017, public records show. More than 400 people were arrested in 2016 for public consumption of marijuana, according to D.C. police arrest records obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request. Records show 78 had been arrested as of April5. That compares with 142 people arrested in 2015, the year that marijuana use but not the sale of marijuana became legal in the city . Arrests for distribution of marijuana also nearly tripled last year from 80 in 2015 to 220 in 2016, according to the data. As of April5, 79 people had been arrested for distribution. The data include arrests by D.C. police and other law enforcement agencies in the city. Watch more! As of Feb. 26, 2015 marijuana was made legal in D.C.sort of. Here are the ins and outs of the complex pot law. In an email, D.C. police spokesman Dustin Sternbeck said the department had "focused its drug enforcement efforts on illegal sales," leading to an increase in arrests for distribution. Legalization has led to more arrests for public consumption, Sternbeck said, even though smoking pot outside is still against the law. Some advocates criticized the increase in arrests, saying they disproportionately affected poor people and minorities. Jonathan Smith, executive director of the Washington Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights and Urban Affairs, an advocacy group that studied marijuana arrests before legalization, said the number of arrests was "very troubling." "A rise in marijuana enforcement, especially at a time of historic and dropping levels of crime in the District, suggests a return to failed practices of overpolicing and underserving communities of color," Smith said. Adam Eidinger, the head of DCMJ, an advocacy group that lobbied for marijuana legalization in the District, was arrested twice in April after handing out free joints near the Capitol. He said the right to smoke marijuana in the District could only be enjoyed by "those who own private property," whereas renters and those in public housing were left out. "A lot of it is people not realizing they can't smoke in public," he said of the increase in arrests. "A lot of it is people who have no place else to go." Peter Hermann contributed to this report.
gens_article:
The federal government has been busting social media for marijuana — in part, the government wants to stop people from committing harm on a street named after Cesar Chavez in a gay day of celebration and legalization.
The media industry is fighting back, as experts and citizens are posting videos and pictures of stoned people on social media. A legal clinic at the Metropolitan Medical Center in Washington is processing 3,000 addicts, treating 6,000 addicts a month — more than twice the population of the District.
The D.C. public health department hopes the crackdown will have only one outcome, but its emphasis on the crush of photos and videos sharing the history of the drug and its origin is disappointing.
As the D.C. Health Department moves to crack down on social media and marijuana use, individuals are warning about the growing popularity of cannabis in the shadows.
Here’s how the D.C. Public Health Department compares the number of St. Patrick’s Day and Halloween martinis in D.C.:
Between the two days in 2015, there were 7,921 legalized marijuana drinkers — or 25,437 people — who were on the streets that same day — in total, according to the health department. That’s an 8 percent increase compared to 2015, as officials investigated two major marijuana busts: the NYPD’s Route 128 and Anne Arundel Avenue dispensary raided by federal agents.
Six of the 17,000 people sampled in the two dispensaries that raided by police during Saturday morning raids occurred in DC, according to the health department.
And the portrait of the public, says the D.C. Health Department, also shows the number of cannabis users — those who caught the drug — rose sharply between the same period in 2015 and 2016.
"And as federal employees become more marijuana savvy and learn about street use and the use of it, so will more people," said Alexis M. Koopchuk, an assistant director at the research office at Washington University in St. Louis.
The D.C. Public Health Department’s annual marijuana-awareness survey shows nearly 50 percent of respondents said they didn’t believe pot has had enough of popping up on the streets.
Nicollette LeRoux writes for Washingtonian. Follow her on Twitter @nikolwulroux.
